metadata.titleEn: Homogenized solar radiation data set over Japan (1870-2015)
metadata.description: This dataset includes the observed surface incident solar radiantion, and sunshine duration derived soalr radiation, and their homogenized series at 156 meteorological stations in Japan from 1870 to 2015. According to Yang's method, the surface solar radiation is calculated from the observed sunshine duration hours, and then the breakpoints of unnatural factors in the data series are adjusted by RH test homogenization method, so as to obtain the regional homogenized monthly solar radiation data set in Japan.
metadata.instructions:
File naming: data is stored in text format, and each site corresponds to a text. The file is named "XXXXX. TXT", where xxxxx is the WMO station ID of the site. Station_ Information.tx records the WMO ID and longitude of the site（ °）、 Latitude（ °） And elevation (m) information.
Data reading mode: all files in the data set can be directly opened by text program (such as Notepad), the first column is year, the second column is month, the third column is the observed surface solar radiation data, the fourth column is the sunshine duration derived solar radiation, the fifth column is the homogenized series of the third column and the sixth column is the homogenized series of the foruth column. The data default value is set as NaN.

background: The amount of solar radiation incident at the surface (Rs) is determined mainly by atmospheric clouds and aerosols as well as solar elevation. Rs has been linked to observed variable decadal warming rates. Existing studies have shown that observed Rs data may have major inhomogeneity problems because of sensitivity drift and instrument replacement. In particular, it has been shown that measurement biases can explain discrepancies between observed and simulated Rs decadal variability. The metadata of Rs observations, including instruments, measurement methods, instrument calibrations, and changes in stations, are essential information to examine the homogeneity of the observed Rs.
research objective: This study provides metadata and reference data to homogenize observed Rs data over China. With this information, it can be explicitly claimed that the sensitivity drift from 1957 to 1989 can be attributed to the pyranometers used to measure diffuse and total solar radiation, whereas measurements of direct solar radiation (Rsdir) were not impaired.
challenges: Existing studies have shown that observed Rs data may have major inhomogeneity problems because of sensitivity drift and instrument replacement. Another great challenge in homogenizing observed Rs data is finding homogenous reference data. Rs exhibits strong spatial variation, and stations measuring Rs are very sparsely distributed. Therefore, neighboring stations cannot be used as reference stations to homogenize observed Rs data.
methods: In this study, intercomparisons of observation-based (observed Rs and SunDu-derived Rs) and model-based (climate models, reanalyses, and satellite retrievals) estimates have been carried out. An open-source software package, RHtest4, was used to perform the homogenization. In this study, the monthly Rs were homogenized using two methods: mean adjusted and quantile-matching (Q-M) adjusted.
dataset: SunDu was then used to calculate Rs from 1950 to 2012 at each station on a daily scale and averaged to generate monthly averages. Detailed validation information for the SunDu-derived Rs can be found in Wang, which shows that Rs can be calculated accurately from SunDu data from daily to decadal time scales. Monthly Rs from historical runs of 48 CMIP5 ESMs were downloaded for this research. The historical runs covered the period from 1850 to 2005, a choice which was forced by atmospheric composition changes from both anthropogenic and natural sources.
findings: Rs averaged over 105 stations in China decreased at approximately 2.9 W m−2 per decade from 1961 to 1990 and remained stable afterward. This decadal variability is confirmed by the observed Rsdir and diurnal temperature ranges, and can be reproduced by high-quality Earth System Models. However, neither satellite retrievals nor reanalyses can accurately reproduce such decadal variability over China.

background: Surface incident solar radiation G determines our climate and environment, and has been widely observed with a single pyranometer since the late 1950s. Such observations have suggested a widespread decrease between the 1950s and 1980s (global dimming), that is, at a rate of 23.5 W m22 decade 21 (or 22% decade21) from 1960 to 1990. Since the early 1990s, the diffuse and direct components of G have been measured independently, and a more accurate G has been calculated by summing these two measurements.
research objective: In this paper, the authors used 17 years (1995–2011) of parallel measurements by the two methods from nearly 50 stations to test whether these two measurement methods of G provide similar long-term trends.
methods: We investigated the relationship between trend differences derived from the two measurement methods and trends of G. We first averaged the data in Fig. 7a over the four networks, and the results are shown in Table 2. We further plotted the differences in trends as derived from the two measurement methods against the average trend of G at stations where both trends pass a 5 0.05 confidence test (Fig. 8).
dataset: We collected 17 years of G data (1995–2011) as measured by the two methods from nearly 50 stations.
findings: The results show that although measurements of G by the two methods agree very well on a monthly time scale, the long-term trend from 1995 to 2011 determined by the single pyranometer is 2–4 W m22 decade 21 less than that from the summation method. This difference of trends in the observed G is statistically significant.

Definition.Question: What does 'homogenization of observed Rs data' mean in the context of solar radiation datasets?
Definition.Answer: Homogenization of observed Rs data involves adjusting the data series to account for non-natural factors such as sensitivity drift and instrument replacement, which can cause major inhomogeneity problems. It includes using methods like RH-test to adjust for breakpoints in data series.

Definition.Question: What are 'SunDu-derived Rs' and why are they significant in solar radiation data collection?
Definition.Answer: SunDu-derived Rs refers to solar radiation data calculated from observed sunshine duration (SunDu). This method is significant because it provides an alternative way to estimate solar radiation, especially when direct measurements are not available, and is validated to calculate accurately from daily to decadal time scales.

Comparison.Question: How do the data homogenization methods used for solar radiation data in Japan compare to those applied in China in terms of addressing non-natural factors?
Comparison.Answer: The homogenization methods used in Japan involve adjusting data series using RH-test methods to address non-natural factors. In China, the study employs RHtest4 software and uses mean adjusted and quantile-matching adjustments. Both approaches aim to tackle inhomogeneity due to sensitivity drift and instrument replacement.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the challenges faced when collecting solar radiation data over China compared to Japan, particularly in terms of spatial variation and station distribution?
Comparison.Answer: In China, a significant challenge is the strong spatial variation of solar radiation and the sparse distribution of stations, making it difficult to find homogeneous reference data. The Japanese dataset does not explicitly mention these challenges, indicating potentially different spatial distribution issues.

Comparison.Question: How do the measurement methods of solar radiation using a single pyranometer compare to those using combined diffuse and direct components in terms of capturing long-term trends?
Comparison.Answer: The measurement method using a single pyranometer tends to show a long-term trend that is 2–4 W m−2 per decade less than the trend derived from summing diffuse and direct components. This indicates that the summation method may provide a more accurate representation of long-term trends.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn about the impact of instrument sensitivity drift and replacement on the homogeneity of solar radiation datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: Existing studies have shown that observed solar radiation data may have major inhomogeneity problems due to sensitivity drift and instrument replacement. These factors can cause discrepancies between observed and simulated solar radiation variability. Specifically, sensitivity drift from 1957 to 1989 has been attributed to the pyranometers used, affecting the homogeneity of observed data.

Interpretation.Question: How do differences in data collection methods affect the long-term trends observed in solar radiation measurements?
Interpretation.Answer: The long-term trend determined by single pyranometer measurements from 1995 to 2011 is 2–4 W m−2 decade−1 less than the trend observed by summing diffuse and direct components. This difference is statistically significant, indicating that the choice of measurement method can significantly impact the observed long-term trends in solar radiation.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies are effective in homogenizing solar radiation data, and how do they address the challenges of sparse station distribution?
Interpretation.Answer: The study uses intercomparisons between observed and model-based estimates and employs the RHtest4 software for homogenization. Homogenization was performed using mean adjusted and quantile-matching methods. However, a challenge is the strong spatial variation of solar radiation and the sparse distribution of measurement stations, making it difficult to find homogeneous reference data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to find homogenous reference data for solar radiation measurements, and what methods can be used to overcome these challenges?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: It is challenging to find homogenous reference data for solar radiation measurements due to the strong spatial variation of solar radiation and the sparse distribution of measuring stations. To overcome these challenges, intercomparisons of observation-based and model-based estimates can be used, along with tools like open-source software packages for homogenization.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to discrepancies in long-term trends of solar radiation measurements when using different data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Discrepancies in long-term trends of solar radiation measurements arise when different data collection methods, such as using a single pyranometer versus summing diffuse and direct components, are used. These differences can be statistically significant, leading to variations in the long-term trends observed.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences on data homogeneity when using different methods to estimate solar radiation from observed sunshine duration?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of different methods to estimate solar radiation from observed sunshine duration can lead to significant inhomogeneity in the data due to sensitivity drift and instrument replacement. This can result in discrepancies between observed and simulated solar radiation decadal variability, as observed Rs data may have major inhomogeneity problems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the likely effects on the accuracy of solar radiation datasets when integrating multiple data sources, such as observational and model-based estimates?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiple data sources like observational and model-based estimates can help in verifying and refining solar radiation datasets. However, challenges arise in ensuring the homogeneity of the data, as there may be strong spatial variations and sparse station distribution, making it difficult to find homogeneous reference data. Accurate integration can improve dataset quality, but discrepancies may still exist, particularly in reproducing decadal variability.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of homogenizing observed solar radiation data across different regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes include addressing major inhomogeneity problems in observed solar radiation data caused by sensitivity drift and instrument replacement, ensuring accurate representation of decadal variability, and using metadata and homogeneous reference data to validate the observations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of using a combination of observed and model-based estimates in solar radiation research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals are to perform intercomparisons that can help in understanding the differences and similarities between various data sources, improving the accuracy and homogeneity of solar radiation datasets through methods like mean adjusted and quantile-matching adjusted homogenization.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the homogenization of solar radiation data collected over a long period across multiple meteorological stations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Homogenization of solar radiation data is achieved using methods such as the RH-test, which adjusts for non-natural breakpoints in data series. In particular, monthly solar radiation data are homogenized using mean adjusted and quantile-matching adjusted methods to address issues such as sensitivity drift and instrument replacement.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in software tools contribute to the homogenization of observed solar radiation data?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in software tools, such as the open-source software package RHtest4, contribute to the homogenization of observed solar radiation data by providing methods like mean adjustment and quantile-matching adjustment to address inhomogeneity issues.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and reference data are necessary to accurately homogenize solar radiation data in regions with sparse station distribution?
Enablement.Answer: Accurate homogenization of solar radiation data in regions with sparse station distribution requires homogenous reference data, which is challenging due to the strong spatial variation of solar radiation and the sparse distribution of measurement stations.

Expectation.Question: Why might neighboring stations not be suitable as reference points for homogenizing observed solar radiation data?

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using the RH-test homogenization method for addressing inhomogeneity issues in solar radiation data collection?
Judgmental.Answer: The RH-test homogenization method is considered effective as it is specifically used to adjust for non-natural breakpoints in data series, thereby helping in the homogenization of solar radiation observations. This method has been applied to correct sensitivity drift and instrument replacement issues in solar radiation data collection, as evidenced by its application in the dataset from Japan.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the challenges faced when using neighboring stations as reference points for homogenizing solar radiation data?
Judgmental.Answer: Using neighboring stations as reference points poses significant challenges due to the strong spatial variation in solar radiation (Rs) and the sparse distribution of measurement stations. This makes it difficult to find homogenous reference data, which is crucial for accurate homogenization of observed Rs data.

Judgmental.Question: In your view, how do the differences in long-term trends observed between single pyranometer measurements and the summation method impact the reliability of solar radiation datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: The differences in long-term trends observed between single pyranometer measurements and the summation method are significant, as measurements using the summation method showed a 2–4 W m² decade⁻¹ greater trend than the single pyranometer. This discrepancy affects the reliability of solar radiation datasets, highlighting the importance of using comprehensive measurement methods for accurate long-term trend analysis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the techniques used to address inhomogeneity in solar radiation datasets and discuss their effectiveness.
Request/Directive.Answer: Inhomogeneity in solar radiation datasets is addressed using methods such as the RH-test for homogenizing data series by adjusting for non-natural breakpoints. The mean adjusted and quantile-matching (Q-M) adjusted methods were applied to monthly radiation data. The effectiveness of these methods is demonstrated in the study, which accurately reproduced decadal variability confirmed by high-quality Earth System Models, despite challenges like sensitivity drift and sparse station distribution.
